words.definition: showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
words.example: She was meticulous in her work, ensuring every detail was perfect.

words.definition: representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class.
words.example: He was the quintessential gentleman, polite and gracious to everyone he met.

words.definition: present, appearing, or found everywhere.
words.example: Smartphones are ubiquitous these days, with almost everyone using one.

words.definition: A gentle wind or current of air.
words.example: The breeze rustled the leaves on the trees.

words.definition: The time of day immediately following sunset.
words.example: The sky turned shades of orange and purple during dusk.

words.definition: Great joy, amusement, or happiness.
words.example: Their laughter filled the room with mirth.

words.definition: The occurrence of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way.
words.example: Finding a hundred-dollar bill on the ground was pure serendipity.

words.definition: Lasting for a very short time.
words.example: The beauty of the sunset was ephemeral, gone within moments.

words.definition: Representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class.
words.example: She is the quintessential romantic heroine.

words.definition: Accept something reluctantly but without protest.
words.example: She seemed to acquiesce to the decision, albeit unwillingly.

words.definition: A mode of behavior or way of thought peculiar to an individual.
words.example: One of his idiosyncrasies is always wearing mismatched socks.

words.definition: Displaying or having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed.
words.example: On a hot summer day, the cat lay languid in the shade.

words.definition: Denoting a period of time in the past that was idyllically happy and peaceful.
words.example: She recalled the halcyon days of her youth with fondness.

words.definition: The partially shaded outer region of the shadow cast by an opaque object.
words.example: The moon's penumbra caused a subtle eclipse, noticeable to those who knew where to look.

words.definition: A person who acts obsequiously toward someone important in order to gain advantage.
words.example: The CEO was surrounded by sycophants who agreed with every word he said.

words.definition: The appearance of being true or real.
words.example: The novel's attention to detail gave it a sense of verisimilitude.

words.definition: Something short-lived or transient.
words.example: The mayfly is an ephemeron, with a lifespan of just a single day.

words.definition: Exceedingly idealistic; unrealistic and impractical.
words.example: His quixotic plan to build a city on the moon was met with skepticism.

words.definition: Reserved, modest, and shy.
words.example: She gave a demure smile in response to the compliment.

words.definition: A solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases.
words.example: The new policy was not a panacea for the economy's problems.

words.definition: Something very light, thin, and insubstantial or delicate.
words.example: A gossamer veil of mist hung over the landscape.

words.definition: A soft gentle breeze.
words.example: The zephyr made the day feel cooler than it actually was.

words.definition: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically an unwelcome one.
words.example: The snowstorm in April was an aberration for the region's climate.

words.definition: Think deeply about something; meditate or reflect.
words.example: He would often cogitate on the mysteries of the universe.

words.definition: Vivacious and enthusiastic.
words.example: Her effervescent personality made her the life of the party.

words.definition: Wicked or criminal.
words.example: The villain's nefarious plan was thwarted by the superheroes.

words.definition: Beauty.
words.example: The pulchritude of the sunset left them in awe.

words.definition: Characteristic of or resembling a seraph or seraphim; angelic.
words.example: The choir's seraphic harmony filled the cathedral.

words.definition: To make something better or more tolerable.
words.example: The new law is expected to ameliorate the lives of low-income families.

words.definition: Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior.
words.example: The capricious weather made it difficult to plan outdoor activities.

words.definition: Lacking a plan, purpose, or enthusiasm.
words.example: The meeting was desultory and unproductive.

words.definition: To cause someone to feel drained of energy or vitality; weaken.
words.example: The intense heat can enervate even the most energetic individuals.

words.definition: Intense happiness.
words.example: Her felicity was evident when she received the good news.

words.definition: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
words.example: The garrulous host kept the guests entertained with endless stories.

words.definition: Not conforming with accepted or orthodox standards or beliefs.
words.example: His heterodox views often caused debates within the academic community.

words.definition: Persisting tirelessly.
words.example: The indefatigable worker continued well into the night.

words.definition: To place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.
words.example: The exhibition juxtaposes modern art with classical pieces.

words.definition: Having complex patterns of colors; multicolored.
words.example: The kaleidoscopic display at the festival was mesmerizing.

words.definition: Expressed clearly; easy to understand.
words.example: The professor's explanation was lucid and helped everyone grasp the concept.

words.definition: Render obscure, unclear, or unintelligible.
words.example: The technical jargon in the report served to obfuscate the main points.

words.definition: Put an end to (a rebellion or other disorder), typically by the use of force.
words.example: The uprising was quickly quelled by the government forces.

words.definition: Attractive and impressive through being richly colorful or sumptuous.
words.example: The ballroom was resplendent with lights and decorations.

words.definition: (of a person) reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little.
words.example: The taciturn man spoke only when necessary.

words.definition: Present, appearing, or found everywhere.
words.example: Smartphones are ubiquitous these days, with almost everyone using one.

words.definition: Regard with great respect; revere.
words.example: Many cultures venerate their ancestors, often with elaborate ceremonies.

words.definition: Having or showing a feeling of vague or regretful longing.
words.example: She gave a wistful smile as she reminisced about her childhood.

words.definition: An individual who is attracted to foreign peoples, cultures, or customs.
words.example: As a xenophile, he enjoyed traveling and experiencing different cultures.

words.definition: A wooden crosspiece that is fastened over the necks of two animals and attached to the plow or cart that they are to pull.
words.example: The farmer used a yoke to harness the oxen to the cart.

words.definition: A person who is fanatical and uncompromising in pursuit of their religious, political, or other ideals.
words.example: The zealot was willing to do anything for his cause.

words.definition: The indefinite continued progress of existence and events in the past, present, and future regarded as a whole.
words.example: Time flies when you're having fun.

words.definition: A human being regarded as an individual.
words.example: She is a person of great importance.

words.definition: The time taken by a planet to make one revolution around the sun.
words.example: The year 2024 is a leap year.

words.definition: A method, style, or manner of doing something.
words.example: There are many ways to solve this problem.

words.definition: A period of 24 hours as a unit of time, reckoned from one midnight to the next.
words.example: He works eight hours a day.

words.definition: An object that one need not, cannot, or does not wish to give a specific name to.
words.example: Look at that shiny thing over there!

words.definition: An adult human male.
words.example: The man walked his dog every morning.

words.definition: The earth, together with all of its countries, peoples, and natural features.
words.example: He wants to travel the world.

words.definition: A young human being below the age of puberty or below the legal age of majority.
words.example: The child played in the park.

words.definition: A colorless, transparent, odorless liquid that forms the seas, lakes, rivers, and rain and is the basis of the fluids of living organisms.
words.example: Please bring me a glass of water.

words.definition: The action or habit of estimating something as worthless.
words.example: The report was a comprehensive floccinaucinihilipilification of the proposed plan.

words.definition: Opposition to the disestablishment of the Church of England.
words.example: Antidisestablishmentarianism was a significant political movement in the 19th century.

words.definition: A lung disease caused by inhaling very fine ash and sand dust.
words.example: Pneumonoultramicroscopicsilicovolcanoconiosis is one of the longest words in the English language.

words.definition: The fear of long words.
words.example: Ironically, hippopotomonstrosesquipedaliophobia is itself a very long word.

words.definition: Extraordinarily good; wonderful.
words.example: The performance was supercalifragilisticexpialidocious.

words.definition: Characterized by long words; long-winded.
words.example: The professor's sesquipedalian lecture was difficult to follow.

words.definition: Things that are impossible to understand or comprehend.
words.example: The book is full of incomprehensibilities.

words.definition: The state of being able to achieve honors.
words.example: He has the honorificabilitudinitatibus to be admitted to the society.

words.definition: A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations, especially by a computer.
words.example: The new algorithm significantly reduced the time needed to process the data.

words.definition: To convert (a program) into a machine-code or lower-level form in which the program can be executed.
words.example: Before running the program, you need to compile the source code.

words.definition: To identify and remove errors from (computer hardware or software).
words.example: Debugging the code took longer than writing it.

words.definition: A named section of a program that performs a specific task.
words.example: This function calculates the user's score.

words.definition: To perform or utter repeatedly.
words.example: The loop will iterate over the array until all elements are processed.

words.definition: An element, feature, or factor that is liable to vary or change.
words.example: The variable 'x' stores the value of the input.

words.definition: The arrangement of words and phrases to create well-formed sentences in a language.
words.example: Syntax errors are often easy to fix but can be hard to spot.

words.definition: Relating to, composed of, or involving two things.
words.example: Binary code is the most basic form of data for computers.

words.definition: An essential supporting structure of a building, vehicle, or object.
words.example: The software framework provides a foundation for developing applications.

words.definition: A question, especially one addressed to an official or organization.
words.example: The database query returned the requested information.

words.definition: The part of a website that users interact with directly.
words.example: She specializes in frontend development, focusing on the look and feel of the site.

words.definition: The part of the website that users do not see, responsible for storing and organizing data.
words.example: The backend of the application handles data processing and storage.

words.definition: An object-oriented computer programming language commonly used to create interactive effects within web browsers.
words.example: Javascript is essential for adding dynamic content to web pages.

words.definition: A style sheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in a markup language like HTML.
words.example: CSS is used to define styles for your web pages, including the design, layout, and variations in display for different devices and screen sizes.

words.definition: The standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser.
words.example: HTML tags are used to create and structure online content.

words.definition: A set of functions and procedures allowing the creation of applications that access the features or data of an operating system, application, or other service.
words.example: The Google Maps API allows developers to embed maps into their websites.

words.definition: A free and open-source CSS framework directed at responsive, mobile-first front-end web development.
words.example: Bootstrap offers design templates for typography, forms, buttons, navigation, and other interface components.

words.definition: A fast, small, and feature-rich JavaScript library designed to simplify the client-side scripting of HTML.
words.example: jQuery simplifies HTML document traversing, event handling, animating, and Ajax interactions for rapid web development.

words.definition: An open-source, cross-platform, back-end JavaScript runtime environment that runs on the V8 engine and executes JavaScript code outside a web browser.
words.example: Node.js is used for server-side scripting and building scalable network applications.

words.definition: A declarative, efficient, and flexible JavaScript library for building user interfaces.
words.example: React allows developers to create large web applications that can change data, without reloading the page.

words.definition: A technique for creating fast and dynamic web pages.
words.example: Ajax allows for the updating of web content asynchronously without reloading the whole page.

words.definition: A platform and framework for building single-page client applications using HTML and TypeScript.
words.example: Angular provides a set of well-integrated libraries and features for solving common web app development challenges.

words.definition: A distributed version-control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.
words.example: Git is used to coordinate work among programmers collaboratively developing source code.

words.definition: An open-source JavaScript module bundler.
words.example: Webpack takes modules with dependencies and generates static assets representing those modules.

words.definition: A progressive framework for building user interfaces.
words.example: Vue is designed from the ground up to be incrementally adoptable.

words.definition: A preprocessor scripting language that is interpreted or compiled into Cascading Style Sheets (CSS).
words.example: Sass allows more advanced features than regular CSS, like variables and nested rules.

words.definition: A dynamic, open source programming language with a focus on simplicity and productivity.
words.example: Ruby's elegant syntax is natural to read and easy to write.

words.definition: A server-side web application framework written in Ruby.
words.example: Rails is a model-view-controller (MVC) framework, providing default structures for a database, a web service, and web pages.

words.definition: A strict syntactical superset of JavaScript that adds optional static typing to the language.
words.example: TypeScript is designed for the development of large applications and transcompiles to JavaScript.

words.definition: A source-available cross-platform document-oriented database program.
words.example: MongoDB uses JSON-like documents with optional schemas.

words.definition: A minimal and flexible Node.js web application framework that provides a robust set of features for web and mobile applications.
words.example: Express is often used to build RESTful APIs and web applications.

words.definition: A set of platform as a service products that use OS-level virtualization to deliver software in packages called containers.
words.example: Docker enables developers to package their applications and dependencies into a container that can run on any Linux server.

words.definition: An open-source data query and manipulation language for APIs, and a runtime for fulfilling queries with existing data.
words.example: GraphQL provides a more efficient, powerful, and flexible alternative to REST.

words.definition: A predictable state container for JavaScript apps.
words.example: Redux is used for managing state in complex applications.

words.definition: A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations.
words.example: The search engine uses a complex algorithm to deliver accurate results.

words.definition: A group of binary digits or bits (usually eight) operated on as a unit.
words.example: A byte can represent 256 different values.

words.definition: A hardware or software component that stores data so future requests for that data can be served faster.
words.example: Clearing the cache can solve some browsing issues.

words.definition: Facts and statistics collected together for reference or analysis.
words.example: The company collects user data to improve its services.

words.definition: The process of converting information or data into a code, especially to prevent unauthorized access.
words.example: Encryption helps to secure sensitive data from hackers.

words.definition: A part of a computer system or network that is designed to block unauthorized access while permitting outward communication.
words.example: A strong firewall is essential for protecting a network from intrusions.

words.definition: A unit of information equal to one billion (10^9) or, strictly, 2^30 bytes.
words.example: This file is too large to send; it's over 5 gigabytes.

words.definition: The machines, wiring, and other physical components of a computer or other electronic system.
words.example: Upgrading the hardware can significantly improve a computer's performance.

words.definition: A global computer network providing a variety of information and communication facilities.
words.example: The internet has become an integral part of daily life.

words.definition: The central part of an operating system, responsible for managing the system's resources and the communication between hardware and software components.
words.example: The Linux kernel is the core component of the Linux operating system.

words.definition: Software that is specifically designed to disrupt, damage, or gain unauthorized access to a computer system.
words.example: It's important to have updated antivirus software to protect against malware.

words.definition: A group of two or more computer systems linked together.
words.example: The office network allows employees to share files and resources.

words.definition: The software that supports a computer's basic functions, such as scheduling tasks, executing applications, and controlling peripherals.
words.example: Windows 10 is a widely used operating system.

words.definition: A set of rules governing the exchange or transmission of data between devices.
words.example: The HTTP protocol is used for transferring web pages over the internet.

words.definition: An anonymous function that can be treated like a value.
words.example: Lambda functions in Python are used for creating small, one-time use functions.

words.definition: A micro web framework written in Python.
words.example: Flask is a lightweight WSGI web application framework.

words.definition: A type of parallel programming in which a unit of work runs separately from the main application thread.
words.example: Async functions in JavaScript allow for performing long network requests without blocking the main thread.

words.definition: An agile framework for managing work with an emphasis on software development.
words.example: Scrum is used to organize teams around a goal and improve their efficiency.

words.definition: A web-based DevOps lifecycle tool that provides a Git-repository manager.
words.example: GitLab offers issue tracking, continuous integration, and deployment pipeline features.

words.definition: An open-source platform designed to automate deploying, scaling, and operating application containers.
words.example: Kubernetes helps you manage containerized applications in different deployment environments.

words.definition: A static module bundler for modern JavaScript applications.
words.example: Webpack bundles JavaScript files for usage in a browser.

words.definition: A class of database management systems that do not require a fixed schema.
words.example: NoSQL databases are often used for large sets of distributed data.

words.definition: A predictable state container for JavaScript apps.
words.example: Redux is used together with React to manage state in an application.

words.definition: An Object Data Modeling (ODM) library for MongoDB and Node.js.
words.example: Mongoose provides a straight-forward, schema-based solution to model application data.

words.definition: An intense feeling of deep affection.
words.example: Parents often express their love for their children through hugs and kind words.

words.definition: The place where one lives permanently, especially as a member of a family or household.
words.example: After a long trip, there is nothing better than returning home.

words.definition: Activity involving mental or physical effort done in order to achieve a purpose or result.
words.example: She has a lot of work to do before the deadline.

words.definition: A person whom one knows and with whom one has a bond of mutual affection.
words.example: A good friend will support you in times of need.

words.definition: Feeling or showing pleasure or contentment.
words.example: She felt happy when she saw the surprise party her friends had organized.

words.definition: A young human being below the age of puberty or below the legal age of majority.
words.example: The child played happily in the park.

words.definition: An institution for educating children.
words.example: The school is hosting a science fair next week.

words.definition: Any nutritious substance that people or animals eat or drink or that plants absorb.
words.example: The restaurant is known for its delicious food.

words.definition: A transparent, odorless, tasteless liquid that forms the seas, lakes, rivers, and rain.
words.example: It's important to drink plenty of water every day.

words.definition: The earth, together with all of its countries, peoples, and natural features.
words.example: Traveling gives you the opportunity to see the world.

words.definition: A period of 24 hours as a unit of time, reckoned from one midnight to the next.
words.example: She had a busy day at work.

words.definition: The period of darkness in each twenty-four hours; the time from sunset to sunrise.
words.example: The stars are visible at night.

words.definition: Engage in activity for enjoyment and recreation rather than a serious or practical purpose.
words.example: Children love to play outside.

words.definition: Move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot in turn.
words.example: They decided to walk rather than take the bus.

words.definition: A cloud of gas and dust in outer space, visible in the night sky either as an indistinct bright patch or as a dark silhouette against other luminous matter.
words.example: The Orion Nebula is one of the brightest nebulae visible to the naked eye in the night sky.

words.definition: A massive and extremely remote celestial object, emitting exceptionally large amounts of energy, which typically has a star-like image in a telescope.
words.example: Quasars are believed to be powered by the accretion of material into supermassive black holes in the centers of distant galaxies.

words.definition: The universe seen as a well-ordered whole.
words.example: The cosmos is vast and largely unknown to humanity.

words.definition: A highly magnetized, rotating neutron star that emits beams of electromagnetic radiation out of its magnetic poles.
words.example: Pulsars are detected by the radio waves they emit and are used by astronomers to study the interstellar medium.

words.definition: A planet that orbits a star outside the solar system.
words.example: Thousands of exoplanets have been discovered in the Milky Way galaxy.

words.definition: A stellar explosion that occurs at the end of a star's life cycle.
words.example: A supernova can briefly outshine entire galaxies and radiate more energy than our sun will in its entire lifetime.

words.definition: A system of millions or billions of stars, together with gas and dust, held together by gravitational attraction.
words.example: The Milky Way is the galaxy that contains our Solar System.

words.definition: A small body moving in the solar system that would become a meteor if it entered the earth's atmosphere.
words.example: Meteoroids that enter Earth's atmosphere are called meteors, and if they reach the ground, they are called meteorites.

words.definition: A Russian astronaut.
words.example: Yuri Gagarin, the first human to journey into outer space, was a Soviet cosmonaut.

words.definition: The branch of astronomy concerned with the physical nature of stars and other celestial bodies.
words.example: Astrophysics seeks to understand the universe and our place in it.

words.definition: The quality of being clear and easy to understand.
words.example: The clarity of the instructions helped everyone complete the task efficiently.

words.definition: Combine a number of things into a coherent whole.
words.example: The student synthesized the information from various sources for the research paper.

words.definition: Full of energy and life.
words.example: The city is known for its vibrant nightlife.

words.definition: Fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing.
words.example: The speaker's eloquent speech moved the audience.

words.definition: A subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound.
words.example: He was aware of every nuance in her voice.

words.definition: Attractively unusual or old-fashioned.
words.example: The quaint village is a popular tourist destination.

words.definition: The time at which something is most powerful or successful.
words.example: The empire was at its zenith in the 16th century.

words.definition: Playfully quaint or fanciful, especially in an appealing and amusing way.
words.example: The artist's whimsical illustrations captured the imagination of children and adults alike.

words.definition: Extremely delicate and light in a way that seems too perfect for this world.
words.example: Her voice had an ethereal quality to it that was mesmerizing.

words.definition: Cheerful and friendly.
words.example: The jovial host made everyone feel welcome.

words.definition: A constantly changing pattern or sequence of elements.
words.example: Her dress was a kaleidoscope of colors.

words.definition: A complicated irregular network of passages or paths in which it is difficult to find one's way; a maze.
words.example: The old library was a labyrinth of books and shelves.

words.definition: Situated or occurring between the stars.
words.example: Interstellar space is the physical space within a galaxy beyond the influence of any star system.

words.definition: An artificial body placed in orbit around the earth or moon or another planet in order to collect information or for communication.
words.example: The satellite transmits data back to Earth.

words.definition: Of, determined by, relating to, or resembling the moon.
words.example: Lunar craters can be clearly seen with a telescope.

words.definition: An event in which the shadow of one celestial body falls on another.
words.example: A solar eclipse occurs when the moon passes between the Earth and the sun.

words.definition: A small rocky body orbiting the sun, found mainly between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter.
words.example: The asteroid belt contains many thousands of asteroids.

words.definition: Relating to the universe or cosmos, especially as distinct from the earth.
words.example: Cosmic rays are high-energy particles from outer space.

words.definition: An optical instrument designed to make distant objects appear nearer, containing an arrangement of lenses or of curved mirrors and lenses.
words.example: The Hubble Space Telescope has provided invaluable data on distant stars and galaxies.

words.definition: Of or relating to an orbit or orbits.
words.example: The satellite remained in its orbital path around the Earth.

words.definition: An expert in or student of astronomy.
words.example: The astronomer spent her nights studying the stars.

words.definition: Relating to movement toward a center of gravity.
words.example: Gravitational forces keep the planets in orbit around the sun.

words.definition: A building or place given over to or equipped for observation of natural phenomena, especially in astronomy.
words.example: The observatory is located on a mountaintop for the best view of the night sky.

words.definition: Of, relating to, or determined by the sun.
words.example: Solar panels convert sunlight into electricity.

words.definition: A vehicle used for traveling in space.
words.example: The spacecraft successfully docked with the space station.

words.definition: Friendly, good-natured, or easy to talk to.
words.example: Her affable nature made her well-liked among her peers.

words.definition: Showing a casual and cheerful indifference considered to be callous or improper.
words.example: His blithe disregard for the rules infuriated the officials.

words.definition: Having a meaning that is mysterious or obscure.
words.example: She received a cryptic message that left her puzzled.

words.definition: Curious or unusual in a way that provokes dry amusement.
words.example: His droll humor often left the crowd in stitches.

words.definition: Filled with or characterized by a lively energy and excitement.
words.example: The crowd was exuberant after the thrilling performance.

words.definition: Having or displaying a passionate intensity.
words.example: He spoke with fervent enthusiasm about his research.

words.definition: Fluent and voluble but insincere and shallow.
words.example: She was put off by his glib answers to serious questions.

words.definition: Create difficulties for (someone or something), resulting in delay or obstruction.
words.example: Heavy snow hindered the rescue efforts.

words.definition: Like an idyll; extremely happy, peaceful, or picturesque.
words.example: They enjoyed an idyllic walk through the countryside.

words.definition: Fond of or characterized by joking; humorous or playful.
words.example: His jocular manner made him the life of the party.

words.definition: An acquired or natural skill at performing a task.
words.example: She has a knack for making people feel at ease.

words.definition: (especially of a person's body) thin, supple, and graceful.
words.example: The dancers were admired for their lithe figures.

words.definition: The natural agent that stimulates sight and makes things visible.
words.example: The light from the sun takes about 8 minutes to reach Earth.

words.definition: A fixed luminous point in the night sky which is a large, remote incandescent body like the sun.
words.example: The nearest star to Earth is the Sun.

words.definition: The natural satellite of the Earth, visible (chiefly at night) by reflected light from the sun.
words.example: The moon's gravitational pull causes the ocean tides on Earth.

words.definition: A celestial body moving in an elliptical orbit around a star.
words.example: Earth is the third planet from the sun in our solar system.

words.definition: The region of the atmosphere and outer space seen from the earth.
words.example: At night, the sky is filled with stars.

words.definition: The curved path of a celestial object or spacecraft around a star, planet, or moon.
words.example: The International Space Station orbits the Earth approximately every 90 minutes.

words.definition: All existing matter and space considered as a whole; the cosmos.
words.example: The universe is constantly expanding.

words.definition: The force that attracts a body toward the center of the earth, or toward any other physical body having mass.
words.example: Gravity is what keeps the planets in orbit around the sun.

words.definition: A continuous area or expanse that is free, available, or unoccupied.
words.example: Astronauts explore outer space.

words.definition: The planet on which we live; the world.
words.example: Earth is the only planet known to support life.

words.definition: The envelope of gases surrounding the earth or another planet.
words.example: The atmosphere of Earth protects us from harmful solar radiation.

words.definition: A system of millions or billions of stars, together with gas and dust, held together by gravitational attraction.
words.example: The Milky Way is the galaxy that contains our Solar System.

words.definition: A celestial object consisting of a nucleus of ice and dust and, when near the sun, a ‘tail’ of gas and dust particles pointing away from the sun.
words.example: Comets are sometimes called 'dirty snowballs' because of their composition.

words.definition: A meeting of supporters or members of a specific political party or movement.
words.example: The party held a caucus to elect its new leadership.

words.definition: Involving the agreement or cooperation of two political parties that usually oppose each other's policies.
words.example: The bill received bipartisan support in the Senate.

words.definition: A body of voters in a specified area who elect a representative to a legislative body.
words.example: The candidate visited her constituency to understand their concerns better.

words.definition: The profession, activity, or skill of managing international relations.
words.example: Diplomacy is essential in resolving international conflicts.

words.definition: An action such as a prolonged speech that obstructs progress in a legislative assembly.
words.example: The senator used a filibuster to delay the vote on the bill.

words.definition: Manipulate the boundaries of (an electoral constituency) to favor one party or class.
words.example: Accusations of gerrymandering surfaced after the district lines were redrawn.

words.definition: Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others.
words.example: The country exerted its hegemony over the region through economic influence.

words.definition: A system of ideas and ideals, especially one that forms the basis of economic or political theory and policy.
words.example: The political party's ideology was based on social equality and justice.

words.definition: The theory or philosophy of law.
words.example: He studied the jurisprudence of international law.

words.definition: A person who takes part in an organized attempt to influence legislators.
words.example: The lobbyist advocated for environmental protection laws.

words.definition: An official order or commission to do something.
words.example: The government was given a clear mandate to reform the tax system.

words.definition: Patriotic feeling, principles, or efforts.
words.example: The rise of nationalism in the country led to significant political changes.

words.definition: A visible mass of condensed water vapor floating in the atmosphere, typically high above the ground.
words.example: The sky was filled with white, fluffy clouds.

words.definition: The star at the center of the solar system, which is a source of light and heat for the planets orbiting it.
words.example: The sun provides the energy needed for life to thrive on Earth.

words.definition: The invisible gaseous substance surrounding the earth, a mixture mainly of oxygen and nitrogen.
words.example: Plants produce oxygen that animals need to breathe the air.

words.definition: A transparent, odorless, tasteless liquid, a compound of hydrogen and oxygen, H2O, freezing at 32°F or 0°C and boiling at 212°F or 100°C, which is essential for most plant and animal life.
words.example: Water covers about 71% of the Earth's surface.

words.definition: Combustion or burning, in which substances combine chemically with oxygen from the air and typically give out bright light, heat, and smoke.
words.example: The campers gathered around the fire to keep warm.

words.definition: A large natural elevation of the earth's surface rising abruptly from the surrounding level; a large steep hill.
words.example: The mountain's peak was covered with snow.

words.definition: A large natural stream of water flowing in a channel to the sea, a lake, or another river.
words.example: The river flowed gently through the valley.

words.definition: The expanse of salt water that covers most of the earth's surface and surrounds its landmasses.
words.example: The sea was calm, with waves gently lapping at the shore.

words.definition: A large area covered chiefly with trees and undergrowth.
words.example: The forest was dense with a variety of trees and plants.

words.definition: Hard, solid nonmetallic mineral matter of which rock is made, especially as a building material.
words.example: The path was paved with smooth stones.

words.definition: A piece of land surrounded by water.
words.example: The island was a popular destination for tourists seeking a tropical getaway.

words.definition: A large body of water surrounded by land.
words.example: The lake was so clear that you could see the fish swimming below.

words.definition: A loose granular substance, typically pale yellowish brown, resulting from the erosion of siliceous and other rocks and forming a major constituent of beaches, riverbeds, the seabed, and deserts.
words.example: The children built castles out of the sand on the beach.

words.definition: A visible mass of condensed water vapor floating in the atmosphere, typically high above the ground.
words.example: The sky was filled with white, fluffy clouds.

words.definition: The star at the center of the solar system, which is a source of light and heat for the planets orbiting it.
words.example: The sun provides the energy needed for life to thrive on Earth.

words.definition: The invisible gaseous substance surrounding the earth, a mixture mainly of oxygen and nitrogen.
words.example: Plants produce oxygen that animals need to breathe the air.

words.definition: A transparent, odorless, tasteless liquid, a compound of hydrogen and oxygen, H2O, freezing at 32°F or 0°C and boiling at 212°F or 100°C, which is essential for most plant and animal life.
words.example: Water covers about 71% of the Earth's surface.

words.definition: Combustion or burning, in which substances combine chemically with oxygen from the air and typically give out bright light, heat, and smoke.
words.example: The campers gathered around the fire to keep warm.

words.definition: A large natural elevation of the earth's surface rising abruptly from the surrounding level; a large steep hill.
words.example: The mountain's peak was covered with snow.

words.definition: A large natural stream of water flowing in a channel to the sea, a lake, or another river.
words.example: The river flowed gently through the valley.

words.definition: The expanse of salt water that covers most of the earth's surface and surrounds its landmasses.
words.example: The sea was calm, with waves gently lapping at the shore.

words.definition: A large area covered chiefly with trees and undergrowth.
words.example: The forest was dense with a variety of trees and plants.

words.definition: Hard, solid nonmetallic mineral matter of which rock is made, especially as a building material.
words.example: The path was paved with smooth stones.

words.definition: A piece of land surrounded by water.
words.example: The island was a popular destination for tourists seeking a tropical getaway.

words.definition: A large body of water surrounded by land.
words.example: The lake was so clear that you could see the fish swimming below.

words.definition: A loose granular substance, typically pale yellowish brown, resulting from the erosion of siliceous and other rocks and forming a major constituent of beaches, riverbeds, the seabed, and deserts.
words.example: The children built castles out of the sand on the beach.

words.definition: The right or condition of self-government.
words.example: The region was granted autonomy and became a federated state.

words.definition: An alliance for combined action, especially a temporary alliance of political parties.
words.example: The two parties formed a coalition to create a majority government.

words.definition: A political leader who seeks support by appealing to popular desires and prejudices.
words.example: The demagogue gained popularity by promising tax cuts and other benefits.

words.definition: Give the right to vote to.
words.example: The amendment enfranchised citizens above the age of 18.

words.definition: Relating to a state governor or the office of state governor.
words.example: The gubernatorial election will take place in November.

words.definition: Currently holding office.
words.example: The incumbent president is running for a second term.

words.definition: Make or enact laws.
words.example: Congress has the power to legislate on federal matters.

words.definition: A strong supporter of a party, cause, or person.
words.example: She is known for her partisan views on the healthcare system.

words.definition: The minimum number of members of an assembly or society that must be present at any of its meetings to make the proceedings of that meeting valid.
words.example: The meeting was adjourned because there was no quorum.

words.definition: A general vote by the electorate on a single political question that has been referred to them for a direct decision.
words.example: The country held a referendum to decide on the new constitution.

words.definition: The indefinite continued progress of existence and events in the past, present, and future regarded as a whole.
words.example: Time is a dimension in which events can be ordered from the past through the present into the future.

words.definition: The time taken by a planet to make one revolution around the sun.
words.example: A year on Earth is 365 days, but a year on Mars is 687 Earth days.

words.definition: The earth, together with all of its countries, peoples, and natural features.
words.example: The world is a complex ecosystem where every species plays a role.

words.definition: The natural agent that stimulates sight and makes things visible.
words.example: The light from the sun takes about 8 minutes to reach Earth.

words.definition: A fixed luminous point in the night sky which is a large, remote incandescent body like the sun.
words.example: The nearest star to Earth is the sun.

words.definition: The natural satellite of the earth, visible (chiefly at night) by reflected light from the sun.
words.example: The moon's gravitational pull causes the rise and fall of ocean tides on Earth.

words.definition: A celestial body moving in an elliptical orbit around a star.
words.example: There are eight planets in the solar system.

words.definition: The region of the atmosphere and outer space seen from the earth.
words.example: The sky appears blue during the day due to the scattering of sunlight by the atmosphere.

words.definition: All existing matter and space considered as a whole; the cosmos.
words.example: The universe is believed to be at least 13.8 billion years old.

words.definition: The force that attracts a body toward the center of the earth, or toward any other physical body having mass.
words.example: Gravity is the force that keeps planets in orbit around the sun.

words.definition: A continuous area or expanse that is free, available, or unoccupied.
words.example: Astronauts explore outer space to learn more about the universe.

words.definition: The third planet from the sun in the solar system, orbited by one moon and with a life-supporting atmosphere.
words.example: Earth is the only known planet to support life.

words.definition: The envelope of gases surrounding the earth or another planet.
words.example: The Earth's atmosphere is composed mainly of nitrogen and oxygen.

words.definition: The agreement or cooperation of two political parties that usually oppose each other's policies.
words.example: The bill was passed with strong bipartisanship support.

words.definition: A meeting of supporters or members of a specific political party or movement.
words.example: The party held a caucus to choose its leadership.

words.definition: A voting member of a community or organization and having the power to appoint or elect.
words.example: The senator met with constituents to discuss local issues.

words.definition: The profession, activity, or skill of managing international relations.
words.example: Diplomacy is essential in resolving international conflicts.

words.definition: An action such as a prolonged speech that obstructs progress in a legislative assembly.
words.example: The senator used a filibuster to delay the vote on the bill.

words.definition: Manipulate the boundaries of (an electoral constituency) to favor one party or class.
words.example: The district was gerrymandered to ensure the incumbent's re-election.

words.definition: Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others.
words.example: The country exerted its hegemony over the region through economic influence.

words.definition: A system of ideas and ideals, especially one that forms the basis of economic or political theory and policy.
words.example: The political party's ideology focuses on social equality and economic reform.

words.definition: The theory or philosophy of law.
words.example: The judge's decision was based on established jurisprudence.

words.definition: A person who takes part in an organized attempt to influence legislators.
words.example: The lobbyist advocated for environmental protection laws.

words.definition: A celestial object consisting of a nucleus of ice and dust and, when near the sun, a ‘tail’ of gas and dust particles pointing away from the sun.
words.example: Halley's Comet is visible from Earth every 75-76 years.

words.definition: A cloud of gas and dust in outer space, visible in the night sky either as an indistinct bright patch or as a dark silhouette against other luminous matter.
words.example: The Orion Nebula is one of the brightest nebulae visible to the naked eye in the night sky.

words.definition: A Russian astronaut.
words.example: Yuri Gagarin, the first human to journey into outer space, was a Soviet cosmonaut.

words.definition: A building or place given over to or equipped for observation of natural phenomena, especially in astronomy.
words.example: The Hubble Space Telescope acts as an observatory in space, capturing images of distant galaxies.

words.definition: A star that suddenly increases greatly in brightness because of a catastrophic explosion that ejects most of its mass.
words.example: A supernova can briefly outshine entire galaxies and radiate more energy than our sun will in its entire lifetime.

words.definition: A massive and extremely remote celestial object, emitting exceptionally large amounts of energy, which typically has a starlike image in a telescope.
words.example: Quasars are believed to be powered by the accretion of material into supermassive black holes in the centers of distant galaxies.

words.definition: A highly magnetized, rotating neutron star that emits a beam of electromagnetic radiation.
words.example: Pulsars are detected by their radio pulses, which are emitted at precise intervals as they rotate.

words.definition: A planet that orbits a star outside the solar system.
words.example: Thousands of exoplanets have been discovered in the Milky Way galaxy.

words.definition: A small body moving in the solar system that would become a meteor if it entered the earth's atmosphere.
words.example: When a meteoroid enters the Earth's atmosphere, it burns up and creates a streak of light known as a meteor.

words.definition: An optical instrument designed to make distant objects appear nearer, containing an arrangement of lenses, or of curved mirrors and lenses, by which rays of light are collected and focused and the resulting image magnified.
words.example: The James Webb Space Telescope is set to explore the universe with unprecedented clarity.

words.definition: A small rocky body orbiting the sun, found mainly between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter in the asteroid belt.
words.example: The asteroid belt contains millions of asteroids, ranging in size from Ceres, which is nearly 600 miles across, to bodies that are less than a mile across.
